title: Domain Incidents
excerpt: Domain Incidents Attacks using malicious or deceitful domains are a significant portion of what we deal with in the brand protection environment. A single domain can host multiple types of violations,...
content: Domain Incidents Attacks using malicious or deceitful domains are a significant portion of what we deal with in the brand protection environment. A single domain can host multiple types of violations, and depending on the violation, the required evidence might change. Most Important : Provide steps to reproduce the attack (Live Proof) so our analysts can easily access the domain and gather further information. Essential Evidence for All Domain Cases When reporting a domain incident, provide: 1. Direct Links with Evidence Provide links with evidence of the infringement, such as: Payment tracking numbers leading to pages with violations. Specific paths showing malicious content. Direct URLs to phishing forms. 2. Screenshots Screenshots showing: Phishing forms or other harmful content. Full URL visible in the address bar. Date and time visible (important for verification). 3. Context About the Case Describe: How it was discovered. Where it was found (search engine, email, social media, etc.). Device and browser used. Location/IP used to access. Any other relevant details. 4. Geo-Fencing Information If you suspect the attack is geo-fenced (only visible from certain locations), also provide: Browser used. Geographic location. Device type (desktop/mobile). IP address if available. Quick Summary: Minimum Evidence Required For all domain-related cases, you must provide: Full URL (e.g., ) Screenshots showing the infringement with date, time, and full URL Case description (context, how found, relevant details) Location, device, and browser used to observe the attack Once submitted, an analyst may contact you for additional details if necessary. Types of Domain-Related Incidents 1. Website Brand Impersonation This occurs when the domain pretends to be the victim's brand, for example, by claiming to be the "official" website. Evidence Required: ‚úÖ Screenshots of the webpage showing brand assets and the full URL. ‚úÖ Screenshots of any statements from the attacker claiming to repre

title: Email Attacks
excerpt: Email Attacks To execute takedowns of phishing emails or malicious email addresses, we need the original email headers . This is the single most important piece of evidence for email-based attacks. Wh...
content: Email Attacks To execute takedowns of phishing emails or malicious email addresses, we need the original email headers . This is the single most important piece of evidence for email-based attacks. Why Email Headers Are Critical Every Internet email message is made up of two parts: The Header - Technical routing and authentication information The Body - The visible message content What Email Headers Contain A full and valid email header provides a detailed log of: The network path taken by the message. Mail servers involved in transmission. Authentication results (SPF, DKIM, DMARC). Sender IP addresses. Timestamps for each hop. Routing information. Critical : Your email client usually hides the full header or displays only basic lines like From, To, Date, and Subject. You must extract the complete raw headers . Common Mistake: Don't Forward Emails! Never forward emails as evidence! Every time you forward an email, the email headers are replaced with new ones. This destroys the original evidence we need to trace the attack. Instead, Extract the Raw Headers The process varies by email client, but generally: Open the email. Look for options like: "Show Original". "View Source". "Message Source". "Raw Message". "View Headers". Copy the complete raw text. Save as a or file. For detailed instructions on how to extract headers from your specific email client, see our Email Headers Guide or search online for "[Your Email Client] view email headers". Evidence Required for Email Attacks Mandatory Evidence ‚úÖ Email Headers (Raw/Original) Must be from the original email (not forwarded). Complete headers from start to finish. Preferably saved as file. Can also be provided as text format. Optional But Helpful Evidence Screenshots of the email showing: Sender information. Subject line. Email body with malicious content. Any embedded links or attachments. Date and time received. Context about the attack: How widespread is the campaign. Number of recipients affected. Type of scam (cr

title: Evidence Guidelines
excerpt: What Makes Evidence Stronger, and What is Not Actionable Understanding what constitutes strong evidence versus counter-evidence is crucial for successful takedown requests. This guide helps you distin...
content: What Makes Evidence Stronger, and What is Not Actionable Understanding what constitutes strong evidence versus counter-evidence is crucial for successful takedown requests. This guide helps you distinguish between actionable violations and legitimate use cases. Brand Impersonation Brand impersonation , or brand spoofing, is a phishing tactic that involves cybercriminals falsely representing themselves as your organization or one of your organization's employees. Evidence vs. Counter Evidence ‚úÖ Strong Evidence ‚ùå Not Actionable / Counter Evidence Usage of the victim logo as its own logo. Having own logo / using victim logo somewhere in content. Use client name as own in page title, main header, footer (c). Mention brand as category or subpage related to service provided. Clearly state to be official support / helpdesk / other department of victim brand. Say that they can help with something, without pretending to be official Representative. Account use name/photo/position of official employee. Former worker; Same name, but not related. Competitors or similar businesses, especially when brand name is very generic. Key Distinction : Brand impersonation requires the bad actor to actively pretend to BE the brand, not just mention or reference it. Trademark and Copyright Infringements TM/CR infringements are not part of brand impersonation (as impersonation is malicious and more powerful evidence). In summary, trademark and copyright infringements include all uses that are not "fair" or "nominative" use. Learn more about Fair Use Doctrine and Trademark & Copyright Fair Trademark Usage For usage to qualify as fair trademark use : The use of the plaintiff's mark is necessary to describe their goods or services. They use only as much of the mark as is necessary to describe the product. Their conduct reflects the accurate relationship they have with the plaintiff. Nominative Trademark Usage For nominative trademark usage , the following elements must be present: The use must a

title: Getting Started
excerpt: Getting Started with Takedown Requests Why is the First Report So Important? At PhishFort, we are committed to protecting your brand against phishing attacks and trademark or brand infringements. We a...
content: Getting Started with Takedown Requests Why is the First Report So Important? At PhishFort, we are committed to protecting your brand against phishing attacks and trademark or brand infringements. We aim to ensure your brand and your customers' safety online. With that, we created this guide that outlines the evidence required for different incident types. Your collaboration is invaluable in helping us build strong cases and submit effective takedown reports. By providing detailed evidence and context, you enable us to act swiftly and decisively against the threats posed by these incidents. Additionally, having this information will help us submit a complete first report quickly and limit any back-and-forth communication or unnecessary delays due to a lack of context. Impact of Complete Reports Submitting a complete and detailed first report is critical to the success of any takedown request. A strong report with the necessary evidence: ‚úÖ Increases the likelihood of resolving the issue on the first attempt. ‚úÖ Impedes scammers from benefiting from unnecessary delays. ‚úÖ Prevents business losses or reputation damage. ‚úÖ Streamlines the process and achieves better outcomes. When Back-and-Forth is Unavoidable In some instances‚Äîespecially with complex phishing attacks‚Äîadditional back-and-forth may be unavoidable to fully understand the context of the incident. This is normal and helps us build the strongest possible case. By ensuring the initial report is thorough, we can streamline the process and achieve better outcomes. Together, we can safeguard your brand's reputation and minimize the impact of malicious activities. What Can and Cannot Be Taken Down? Before jumping into the evidence we need, let's review what can and cannot be taken down. What CANNOT Be Taken Down? Although our mission is to protect brands and customers from cyberattacks, it is important to know that not all content can be taken down from the internet. Certain types of content are protected from takedo

title: PhishFort Reporting Handbook
excerpt: PhishFort Reporting Handbook Welcome to the PhishFort Reporting Handbook. This guide will help you submit complete and effective takedown reports with the right evidence. Quick Start New to reporting ...
content: PhishFort Reporting Handbook Welcome to the PhishFort Reporting Handbook. This guide will help you submit complete and effective takedown reports with the right evidence. Quick Start New to reporting incidents? Start with Getting Started to understand what can be taken down and why complete reports matter. Review Evidence Guidelines to learn what makes evidence stronger and more actionable. Know your incident type? Jump directly to the relevant section in the Documentation Structure below. Check the Quick Reference for a summary of evidence requirements. Need specific information? Use the search bar above to find what you're looking for quickly. Browse the Documentation Structure below to explore all available topics. Documentation Structure Learn why first reports matter, what can be taken down, and evidence best practices. Quick summary table of evidence requirements for all case types. Understand what makes evidence stronger and more effective for takedowns. Requirements and processes for domain-related takedowns and abuse reporting. How to report phishing emails and malicious email campaigns effectively. Reporting phone scams, smishing, and vishing attacks with proper evidence. Report impersonation and abuse on Facebook, Twitter, TikTok, LinkedIn, and YouTube. Handle incidents on WhatsApp, Telegram, and Discord with platform-specific guidance. IP reporting, GitHub, GitBook, APK cases, browser extensions, ads, and search engines. Trademark, copyright, fair use doctrine, ICANN, and UDRP processes. Handling fake news, scams, and bulk reporting scenarios. Need Help? If you need assistance with a specific case type, navigate to the appropriate section using the links above. Each section provides detailed evidence requirements and best practices for successful takedowns.

title: Fair Use Doctrine
excerpt: Fair Use Doctrine The fair use doctrine allows limited use of copyrighted material without permission for purposes such as criticism, commentary, news reporting, education, or research. Fundamental Pr...
content: Fair Use Doctrine The fair use doctrine allows limited use of copyrighted material without permission for purposes such as criticism, commentary, news reporting, education, or research. Fundamental Principle : Fair Use shouldn't cause confusion to users/customers‚Äîthere isn't brand impersonation involved. Types of Fair Use Classic Fair Use Using a trademark to describe goods or services without indicating their source . Purpose : Help prevent monopolies on descriptive terms. Example : "iPhone-compatible charger" (describing compatibility, not claiming to be Apple). Nominative Fair Use (Most Common) Allows use of another's mark to identify their goods/services when they cannot be easily identified otherwise. Example : Media outlets referring to trademarked names for reporting purposes (provided there's no false affiliation suggested). When Does Fair Use Apply? Fair use applies when the mark is used in good faith without causing consumer confusion . Protected Scenarios ‚úÖ News Reporting Referring to trademarks in news stories or commentary. Information provided must be accurate. ‚úÖ Product Reviews Mentioning brand names to identify products for review. Includes critical reviews. ‚úÖ Parody Protected by U.S. law and many other countries. Typically doesn't confuse consumers. ‚úÖ Comparative Advertising Comparing products can include trademarks. Must be non-deceptive. ‚úÖ Compatibility Claims Stating product's compatibility with another brand. "Works with [Brand]". ‚úÖ Identifying Customers Using partner logos in marketing. Only as much as necessary. Requirements for Fair Use Fair Trademark Usage To qualify as fair trademark use: Necessary for Description Use of plaintiff's mark must be necessary to describe goods/services. Minimal Use Only amount necessary for description should be used. Accurate Relationship Usage must reflect true relationship between user and plaintiff. Nominative Trademark Usage To qualify as nominative use: Accurate Reference Must accurately refer to TM owner

title: ICANN & UDRP
excerpt: ICANN & UDRP ICANN Escalations ICANN (Internet Corporation for Assigned Names and Numbers) is a regulatory body for many common Top-Level Domains (TLDs). Coverage ‚úÖ Covered TLDs : .com, .org, .net. ‚ùå ...
content: ICANN & UDRP ICANN Escalations ICANN (Internet Corporation for Assigned Names and Numbers) is a regulatory body for many common Top-Level Domains (TLDs). Coverage ‚úÖ Covered TLDs : .com, .org, .net. ‚ùå NOT Covered : Country code TLDs (ccTLDs) like .sa, .ru, .fr, .io. When to Escalate ICANN escalations are possible when a Registrar is being unresponsive. Requirements : ‚úÖ Domain involves clear infringement (screenshots, URLs, phishing proof). ‚úÖ Case reported through Registrar's proper channels. ‚úÖ Minimum 72 hours have passed since initial report. Timeline ICANN contacts registrar up to 3 times . 15 days wait after each communication. Notice of Breach issued if no response. Average resolution : ~1 month. Last Resort : ICANN escalations should be used as a last resort. If ICANN is unable to resolve, consider UDRP or legal action. UDRP (Uniform Domain-Name Dispute Resolution Policy) The UDRP is a legal framework for resolving disputes between domain name registrants and third-party trademark owners over abusive registration and use of Internet domain names. Reference: WIPO UDRP Guide Key Factors ‚ùå No money back on failure . ‚ö†Ô∏è Significant effort required to fill submissions and maintain communication. ‚è±Ô∏è Timeline : 14-30 days. üìã Requires TM registration . üéØ Requires proof of unfair usage or at least unfair intent. Requirements To file UDRP, you need: ‚úÖ Trademark Registration Domain must include your registered TM. ‚úÖ Proof of Bad Faith Unfair usage of the domain. Bad faith registration intent. ‚úÖ Evidence Package Comprehensive documentation. Timeline of infringement. Proof of harm. When to Consider UDRP Standard takedown failed. ICANN escalation unsuccessful. Domain clearly includes your registered TM. Registrar unresponsive. Strong evidence of bad faith. Cost Considerations Additional cost (varies by provider). No refund if unsuccessful. Legal consultation often needed. More expensive than standard takedowns. ICANN vs UDRP Factor ICANN Escalation UDRP Cost No additional c

title: Trademark & Copyright
excerpt: Trademark & Copyright Infringement At PhishFort, we protect your brand not only from malicious activity but also from TM and CR infringements. Definitions Trademark A trademark is a distinctive symbol...
content: Trademark & Copyright Infringement At PhishFort, we protect your brand not only from malicious activity but also from TM and CR infringements. Definitions Trademark A trademark is a distinctive symbol, phrase, or word that identifies a particular product or service. It serves to legally distinguish one offering from others in the marketplace while also acknowledging the ownership of the brand by the respective company. Protects : Brand identity for selling products or services. Copyright Copyright is a legal term used to describe the rights that creators have over their literary and artistic works. Works covered by copyright range from books, music, paintings, sculpture, and films, to computer programs, databases, advertisements, maps, and technical drawings. (Source: WIPO Copyright ) Protects : Creative expressions. Key Distinction : Copyright protects creative expressions, while trademarks protect brand identity. For DMCA takedowns, only copyright-related claims are applicable. What is a DMCA? The Digital Millennium Copyright Act (DMCA) is a U.S. law enacted in 1998 to address copyright protection in the digital age. It provides a framework for: Copyright holders to request removal of infringing content. Service providers to be protected from liability if they respond promptly. International Context While DMCA is specific to the U.S., many countries have adopted similar laws under the WIPO Copyright Treaty : European Union : EU Copyright Directive. Other jurisdictions : Similar frameworks balancing copyright protection with innovation. Types of Infringement Trademark Infringement Occurs when a trademark is used without permission in a way that causes confusion about the source of goods or services. Common Types : Counterfeiting : Unauthorized use on identical/similar goods. Dilution : Weakening famous trademark's uniqueness. Unauthorized Marketing : Using TM without permission for promotion. Confusing Use : Similar mark on related goods/services. Copyright Infring

title: Discord Takedowns
excerpt: Discord Takedowns Discord presents unique requirements for takedown cases due to its structure, where users, messages, and servers all have distinct identifiers. How to Obtain IDs and Links Go to the ...
content: Discord Takedowns Discord presents unique requirements for takedown cases due to its structure, where users, messages, and servers all have distinct identifiers. How to Obtain IDs and Links Go to the specific user, message, or server causing the issue. Right-click on the element (e.g., user profile or message). Select the three dots and click "Copy Link" . Example Message ID Structure Where: XXXXXXX = Server ID. YYYYYYY = Channel ID. ZZZZZZZ = Message ID. Evidence Requirements User, Message, and Server Information ‚úÖ User ID Right-click user profile ‚Üí three dots ‚Üí "Copy ID". ‚úÖ Message Link Right-click message ‚Üí "Copy Link". ‚úÖ Server ID Copy by logging into the infringing server. ‚úÖ Screenshots Include visible timestamps, usernames, and context. Show the infringing content clearly. ‚úÖ Context Explanation Describe how the reported activity causes harm. ‚úÖ LOA Important : You must be part of the server to collect the necessary details. Ensure your access is active to retrieve the message links and IDs. Return to Messaging ‚Üí | Return to Home ‚Üí

title: Messaging Applications
excerpt: Messaging Applications To ensure we can assist you effectively with reporting messengers, please include a clear statement indicating your intention. Be Specific : Specify if you would like to take do...
content: Messaging Applications To ensure we can assist you effectively with reporting messengers, please include a clear statement indicating your intention. Be Specific : Specify if you would like to take down a WhatsApp account, Telegram channel, or Discord server. Provide the URL or identifier of the account. These should be reported as "Social" incidents. Supported Messaging Platforms WhatsApp ‚Üí Telegram ‚Üí Discord ‚Üí General Requirements All messaging platform takedowns require: ‚úÖ Letter of Authorization (LOA) ‚úÖ Clear identification of the infringing account/channel/server ‚úÖ Screenshots showing the infringement with timestamps ‚úÖ Context explaining the violation Return to Home ‚Üí

title: Telegram Takedowns
excerpt: Telegram Takedowns Telegram presents unique challenges when performing takedowns, as it often ignores standard infringement reports. Platform Limitation : In general, Telegram only takes quick action ...
content: Telegram Takedowns Telegram presents unique challenges when performing takedowns, as it often ignores standard infringement reports. Platform Limitation : In general, Telegram only takes quick action in cases involving severe violations , such as illegal content. Brand impersonation or phishing reports are generally low-priority unless overwhelming evidence is provided. Success Rates Overall success rates for Telegram vary depending on: Type of infringement. Quality of evidence. How the reported infringement violates Telegram's fair use policies. Telegram operates with a very loose enforcement mandate, which our team continuously manages and files escalations for on behalf of customers. Evidence by Type Message ‚úÖ Required : Link to the message. Screenshots showing undeniable evidence of the violation. Include timestamps and dates. Context about it. Legitimate account being impersonated (if possible). LOA. Channel ‚úÖ Required : Link to the Channel. Context about it. Legitimate account being impersonated (if possible). LOA. Group ‚úÖ Required : Link to the group. Context about it. Legitimate account being impersonated (if possible). LOA. Best Practices ‚úÖ Provide overwhelming evidence. ‚úÖ Show clear policy violations. ‚úÖ Document harm to users. ‚úÖ Include customer complaints. ‚ùå Don't expect quick action. ‚ùå Don't rely on brand name alone. ‚ùå Don't submit without clear malicious intent. Return to Messaging ‚Üí | Return to Home ‚Üí

title: WhatsApp Takedowns
excerpt: WhatsApp Takedowns Evidence Requirements Mandatory Evidence ‚úÖ Letter of Authorization (LOA) ‚úÖ Phone Number in wa.me Format Format: . Example: . Important : Sharing the contact directly (e.g., via vCar...
content: WhatsApp Takedowns Evidence Requirements Mandatory Evidence ‚úÖ Letter of Authorization (LOA) ‚úÖ Phone Number in wa.me Format Format: . Example: . Important : Sharing the contact directly (e.g., via vCard or "Share Contact" option) is not sufficient for reporting. ‚úÖ Screenshots with Evidence Clear screenshots capturing the infringement Messages impersonating the client or showing malicious activity Timestamps visible Optional But Recommended Context about the scam or impersonation. Customer reports or complaints. Pattern of behavior (if multiple users affected). Common Mistakes ‚ùå Don't share contacts via vCard - Use wa.me format. ‚ùå Don't provide just phone number - Include wa.me URL. ‚ùå Screenshots without context - Explain the violation. Important : Screenshots showing group member lists or participant details do not necessarily strengthen the case if the rest of the evidence is not provided. Return to Messaging ‚Üí | Return to Home ‚Üí

title: APK Cases
excerpt: APK Cases An APK is an app hosted outside official distribution platforms like Google Play Store or Apple App Store. Important : APK cases are treated as DMCA takedowns . This means we do not require ...
content: APK Cases An APK is an app hosted outside official distribution platforms like Google Play Store or Apple App Store. Important : APK cases are treated as DMCA takedowns . This means we do not require trademark registrations as evidence. Instead, we need proof of copyright violation. Evidence Requirements ‚úÖ Letter of Authorization (LOA) ‚úÖ Proof of Copyright Violation Evidence that the client's copyright is being infringed. ‚úÖ Client Relationship Evidence For sub-clients: proof of legal relationship between partner and end customer. For sub-brands: reference to parent company (mention on website/official app). ‚úÖ For Malicious APKs : Screenshots of phishing behavior. Requests for sensitive information (wallet credentials, banking details). Malware analysis (if available). ‚úÖ Link to Original APK (if screenshots unavailable). Important Notes File vs. Page Takedown : In general, the takedown is performed on the file itself by removing it. The informational page might not be taken down and may remain active. APK takedowns often require more back-and-forth communication as: Apps aren't always inherently malicious. Some are distributed for device compatibility. Proving infringement can be challenging. Return to Home ‚Üí

title: Browser Extensions
excerpt: Browser Extensions Evidence Requirements ‚úÖ Clear Evidence of Copyright Infringement Such as: Screenshots showing brand misuse (logo, brand name). Screenshots of the extension in action (login form, ph...
content: Browser Extensions Evidence Requirements ‚úÖ Clear Evidence of Copyright Infringement Such as: Screenshots showing brand misuse (logo, brand name). Screenshots of the extension in action (login form, phishing behavior). Link to the extension in Chrome/Edge/Firefox store. ‚úÖ Proof of Unauthorized Use Show the extension uses proprietary code without authorization. Demonstrate it mimics official functionality. Prove consumer confusion. ‚úÖ LOA Best Practices ‚úÖ Show the extension in action. ‚úÖ Provide link to official extension (if you have one). ‚úÖ Document user complaints or confusion. ‚úÖ Include store listing URL. Return to Home ‚Üí

title: GitBook Takedowns
excerpt: GitBook Takedowns Evidence Requirements ‚úÖ Full URL Direct link to the infringing GitBook page. ‚úÖ Brief Explanation Context of the attack. How it violates your brand. Type of infringement. ‚úÖ LOA Letter...
content: GitBook Takedowns Evidence Requirements ‚úÖ Full URL Direct link to the infringing GitBook page. ‚úÖ Brief Explanation Context of the attack. How it violates your brand. Type of infringement. ‚úÖ LOA Letter of Authorization. Return to Home ‚Üí

title: GitHub Takedowns
excerpt: GitHub Takedowns Evidence Requirements ‚úÖ Type of Attack Specify: phishing, credential exposure, or other brand infringement. ‚úÖ File Containing the Infringement Provide exact file name. ‚úÖ Location of E...
content: GitHub Takedowns Evidence Requirements ‚úÖ Type of Attack Specify: phishing, credential exposure, or other brand infringement. ‚úÖ File Containing the Infringement Provide exact file name. ‚úÖ Location of Evidence Repository path and file location. Example: . ‚úÖ Lines of Code (for partial infringement) Specify exact lines containing the infringement. Not needed if entire file/repository is infringing. ‚úÖ Context/Incident Explanation Explain why the content infringes on your brand or intellectual property. Best Practices ‚úÖ Be specific about what's infringing. ‚úÖ Provide repository URL. ‚úÖ Specify exact files and lines when possible. ‚úÖ Explain the harm or violation. ‚ùå Don't report entire repositories without specifying infringing parts. ‚ùå Don't submit without clear explanation of infringement. Return to Home ‚Üí

title: Google Ads & Landing Pages
excerpt: Google Ads Impersonations and Malicious Landing Pages PhishFort can carry out takedowns for malicious ads and landing pages. Important : Submit as two separate incidents : One for the ad One for the l...
content: Google Ads Impersonations and Malicious Landing Pages PhishFort can carry out takedowns for malicious ads and landing pages. Important : Submit as two separate incidents : One for the ad One for the landing page Evidence Requirements Mandatory ‚úÖ Ad URL ‚úÖ Landing Page URL ‚úÖ Screenshot of search results showing impersonation Additional (Strengthens Case) Date and time the ad appeared. GCLID values. IP addresses associated with the attack. Best Practices ‚úÖ Screenshot the entire search result page. ‚úÖ Include your ad position vs. the malicious ad. ‚úÖ Show how users could be confused. ‚úÖ Provide geo-location if ad is region-specific. Return to Home ‚Üí

title: IP Reporting
excerpt: IP Reporting Reporting IPs requires extra care and detailed evidence due to the complexities of their use. Important : Many IP addresses host multiple websites, and not all may be malicious. Domain-le...
content: IP Reporting Reporting IPs requires extra care and detailed evidence due to the complexities of their use. Important : Many IP addresses host multiple websites, and not all may be malicious. Domain-level takedowns are usually more effective than targeting entire IPs. Evidence Requirements ‚úÖ Specific URL Evidence Always provide a specific URL associated with the malicious activity hosted on the IP. ‚úÖ Detailed Explanation Describe how the content is harmful or infringing. Include proof of malicious activity (phishing, malware, impersonation). Domain vs. IP Considerations Best Practice : If the same domain is used across multiple IPs, prioritize reporting the domain rather than the IPs. When a TLD is taken down, it cannot change IPs to be up again. When to Report IPs Single-IP hosting with multiple malicious domains. Infrastructure hosting only malicious content. When domain takedowns have failed. When NOT to Report IPs IP hosts legitimate websites alongside malicious ones. Domain-level takedown is possible. Risk of collateral damage to legitimate sites. Malware & Sensitive Content Cases involving malware or NSFW material demand heightened attention. Please clearly flag these cases when reporting so our analysts can prioritize and handle appropriately. Return to Home ‚Üí

title: Scribd Takedowns
excerpt: Scribd Takedowns Evidence Requirements ‚úÖ Name of the Company Being Impersonated ‚úÖ Suspicious URLs (most important) Direct links to infringing documents. ‚úÖ File Titles According to Scribd: "Enter title...
content: Scribd Takedowns Evidence Requirements ‚úÖ Name of the Company Being Impersonated ‚úÖ Suspicious URLs (most important) Direct links to infringing documents. ‚úÖ File Titles According to Scribd: "Enter titles of copyrighted material being infringed upon and, if possible, additional identifying information such as ISBNs, publication dates, etc‚Äîor, if the material is a web page, the URL where the original can be found." ‚úÖ TM Registration Numbers/Documents Especially helpful when sub-brands are targeted. ‚úÖ LOA Return to Home ‚Üí

title: Search Engines
excerpt: Search Engine Cache Removal When unwanted or malicious content continues to appear in search results‚Äîeven in cached form‚Äîyou can request removal of those cached versions. How Cached Removal Works Prer...
content: Search Engine Cache Removal When unwanted or malicious content continues to appear in search results‚Äîeven in cached form‚Äîyou can request removal of those cached versions. How Cached Removal Works Prerequisite : Before a search engine will remove a cached page, the content must actually be unavailable on the live site (returns 404 or has been taken down). The Recrawl Process Search engines use bots (crawlers) to discover and index content. When a page is updated/deleted: Crawler must recrawl the page. This can take days or even a week . Depends on site popularity and crawl frequency. Can be expedited with cache-specific reports. Evidence Requirements ‚úÖ Exact URL as it appears in search results. ‚úÖ Search Engine Name (Google, Bing, etc.). ‚úÖ Cached-Page URL (if available). Important : Report each cached link as a separate incident (one URL = one incident), even if same search term appears across multiple engines. Best Practices ‚úÖ Ensure live page is already down/removed. ‚úÖ Submit to each search engine separately. ‚úÖ Include exact cached URL when available. ‚úÖ Provide context about the original takedown. ‚ùå Don't submit while live page is still active. ‚ùå Don't expect instant removal. ‚ùå Don't bundle multiple URLs in one report. Return to Home ‚Üí

title: Phone-Related Attacks
excerpt: Phone-Related Attacks Smishing (SMS Phishing) Evidence Required ‚úÖ Sender Number (preferable) ‚úÖ Receiver Number ‚úÖ Date, Time, and Timezone of the SMS ‚úÖ Text or Screenshot of the SMS ‚úÖ Brief Description...
content: Phone-Related Attacks Smishing (SMS Phishing) Evidence Required ‚úÖ Sender Number (preferable) ‚úÖ Receiver Number ‚úÖ Date, Time, and Timezone of the SMS ‚úÖ Text or Screenshot of the SMS ‚úÖ Brief Description of the attack (if possible) Phone Scams Evidence Required ‚úÖ Caller Number ‚úÖ Receiver Number ‚úÖ Screenshot of the phone call with date and time ‚úÖ Timezone ‚úÖ Brief Description of the call/attack Best Practices ‚úÖ Do This Include both numbers involved. Specify timezone clearly. Provide screenshots with timestamps. Describe what was said/requested. Explain the impersonation or scam. ‚ùå Don't Do This Don't omit timezone information. Don't provide just phone numbers without context. Don't skip description of the scam. Return to Home ‚Üí

title: Quick Reference
excerpt: Quick Reference: Case Evidence Requirements This table provides a quick summary of evidence requirements. For comprehensive information and detailed guidance on each case type, please refer to the rel...
content: Quick Reference: Case Evidence Requirements This table provides a quick summary of evidence requirements. For comprehensive information and detailed guidance on each case type, please refer to the relevant sections throughout this handbook. Case Evidence Required Comments Website impersonation 1. Original website link 2. Statements of abuse 3. Screenshots showing malicious targeting. Site must be maliciously targeting the brand in question. Social Media Accounts 1. Legitimate account as reference 2. Letter of Authorization 3. Statement of Impersonation 4. 2+ from: impersonating logo/name/post with affiliation claim. Requires minimum of 2 impersonation criteria to be met. Messaging Platforms 1. Platform/messenger name 2. Username 3. Date/timestamp 4. Screenshots of infringing text 5. Summary of malicious activity. Submit as URL, screenshot, or text where visible. Phone scams 1. Caller number 2. Receiver number 3. Timezone 4. Description of conversation 5. SMS text (if applicable). Description should include impersonation statement. TM/Copyright infringement 1. Proof of ownership (TM registration, copyright docs) 2. Evidence of unfair use 3. Letter of Authorization. LoA must match the trademark registration. APK websites 1. Link to original app 2. Screenshots of malicious APK 3. Evidence of brand misuse. - Email attack 1. Email headers (raw/original) 2. Malicious or impersonating content 3. Screenshots of email. Headers must be from original email, not forwarded. Similar/Typo squat domain 1. Domain name 2. Screenshots of content 3. Evidence of malicious use. Typosquat alone is not enough. Higher success if domain has malformed/improper wording (not generic words). Parked page 1. Clear trademark in link 2. Evidence TM is not generic. No legal basis to take down parked pages alone. Attempts performed only when possible. Redirect source 1. Source domain with clear TM 2. Target domain details. Submit target domain as separate incident with comment about redirect. Scams 1.

title: Facebook Takedowns
excerpt: Facebook Takedowns When dealing with Facebook cases, it's important to obtain a direct link to the infringement. This can be highly beneficial depending on the situation at hand. Evidence Requirements...
content: Facebook Takedowns When dealing with Facebook cases, it's important to obtain a direct link to the infringement. This can be highly beneficial depending on the situation at hand. Evidence Requirements Mandatory Evidence ‚úÖ Letter of Authorization (LOA) Learn about LOA requirements ‚Üí ‚úÖ URL or Screenshot of Infringement Profile URL for impersonation. Direct link to posts or comments. Screenshots if links unavailable. ‚úÖ Context Related to the Case Type of violation. How it harms your brand. Any customer reports. Optional But Recommended Legitimate Profile (for impersonation cases). Additional screenshots showing: Timeline of violations. Multiple violations. User engagement/confusion. Getting Direct Links to Infringement For Profile Impersonation Simply copy the profile URL from the address bar. Example : For Posts Click the timestamp/date on the post. Copy the URL from the address bar. Example : For Comments Important : For comments, hide them instead of deleting! This makes evidence more accessible to Facebook's authorities while preventing further harm. How to hide and link to comments : Click the three dots (‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢) on the comment. Select "Hide comment". Right-click the timestamp. Select "Copy link". Share this link in your report. Example : If Links Aren't Available Provide clear screenshots that show: Full URL in address bar. Date/time stamp. The infringing content. Engagement metrics (if relevant). Types of Facebook Violations 1. Profile Impersonation What Qualifies : Using your logo as profile/cover photo. Using your brand name as the page name. Claiming to be official support/customer service. Impersonating executives or employees. Evidence Needed : URL of fake profile. URL of legitimate profile (if available). Screenshots showing impersonation. LOA. 2. Page Impersonation What Qualifies : Fake business pages. Pages claiming official affiliation. Pages using your branding. Evidence Needed : URL of fake page. URL of legitimate page. Screenshots showing violations. LO

title: Social Media Platforms
excerpt: Social Media Platforms Social media platforms can vary significantly in their level of cooperation when handling takedown requests. While some may act swiftly on clear evidence of phishing or maliciou...
content: Social Media Platforms Social media platforms can vary significantly in their level of cooperation when handling takedown requests. While some may act swiftly on clear evidence of phishing or malicious activity, others may require extensive documentation and context to act. Our requests for specific evidence are not arbitrary but rather the result of carefully tested approaches aimed at increasing the likelihood of success. General Requirements for All Social Media Platforms Key Evidence Required 1. Letter of Authorization (LOA) The LOA allows PhishFort to act on behalf of the client for Trademark / Copyright / DMCA infringement cases. What LOA Should Include : Original URLs protected by PhishFort. Company registration number and jurisdiction. Registration numbers and jurisdictions of copyrights and trademarks. Associated brands (if applicable). More complete = Better success rate The more complete the LOA document, the better chances we have to achieve a successful takedown. 2. Detailed Explanation of the Infringement Context is crucial to report the correct type of infringement. Our analysts need a good understanding of the case to evaluate it and submit a compelling report. What to Include : Type of violation (impersonation, TM, copyright, phishing). How it harms your brand. How users might be confused. Any customer complaints or reports. Sending just a link or an image without explanation will not suffice. 3. The Original/Legitimate Profile (If Available) Providing the real profile being impersonated helps us prove which is legitimate. Benefits : Shorter takedown time. Higher success rate. Clearer comparison for platform reviewers. Platform-Specific Guides Each platform has unique policies and requirements. Select your platform below for detailed guidance: Major Platforms Direct links to infringement, legitimate profile, LOA. Special handling for comments and posts. Strict impersonation definition: requires 2+ of display name, profile description, or impersonati

title: LinkedIn Takedowns
excerpt: LinkedIn Takedowns LinkedIn takedown cases often require detailed evidence and context to ensure successful resolution. Types of Violations 1. False Information Incorrect details in the "Experience" s...
content: LinkedIn Takedowns LinkedIn takedown cases often require detailed evidence and context to ensure successful resolution. Types of Violations 1. False Information Incorrect details in the "Experience" section, such as false employment claims. Can be removed : False employment claims in Experience section. Cannot be removed : Profile descriptions (typically). 2. Scams Individuals impersonating someone else or fraudulently associating themselves with a company. Evidence Requirements Key Evidence Needed ‚úÖ Location of the Infringement Identify where the violation occurs (specific section of profile or company page). ‚úÖ Nature of the Harm Explain who is affected and how the content is causing damage. ‚úÖ Reason for the Report Concise explanation of why the content affects your brand. Link it to a violation of LinkedIn's policies (impersonation, fraudulent claims). ‚úÖ Letter of Authorization (LOA) ‚úÖ Direct Link to the Profile/Page Exact URL of the content being reported. ‚úÖ Impersonation Proof Link to the real profile or page of the person/company being mimicked. For Employee Impersonation If impersonation involves a client employee, we might need: Proof of employment. Letter from HR or management. Official company statement. Specific Cases Pre-Made Pages The platform rejects takedown attempts of pre-made pages. Alternative : Claim ownership through LinkedIn's process for associating a page with the primary company profile. False Information in Experience LinkedIn allows removal of false details in the "Experience" section. Example : Someone falsely claiming to work at your company. Important Note : Descriptions in profiles typically cannot be removed. Individual Posts Not typically taken down unless explicit violation of LinkedIn's content guidelines (e.g., phishing or malicious content). Scam or Impersonation Highlight how the profile/page is: Pretending to be someone. Falsely claiming association with a company. Response Times Typically 7-14 days. Complex cases may take longe

title: TikTok Takedowns
excerpt: TikTok Takedowns TikTok has specific requirements that differ from other platforms. They will not act on reports for profiles with a brand's name alone. Critical : TikTok only acts on accounts with an...
content: TikTok Takedowns TikTok has specific requirements that differ from other platforms. They will not act on reports for profiles with a brand's name alone. Critical : TikTok only acts on accounts with an infringing post . Without a post, takedowns cannot be executed. Evidence Requirements Mandatory Evidence ‚úÖ Letter of Authorization (LOA) ‚úÖ Legitimate Profile (MANDATORY) If your legitimate TikTok profile doesn't exist, let us know. We can execute the takedown but with a different process and escalation system. ‚úÖ Link to the Infringing TikTok Post Must be a specific post, not just the profile. Profile name alone is not enough. Optional But Recommended Screenshots of the infringing post. Context about the violation. Evidence of customer confusion. Types of Violations Infringing Posts (Actionable) Posts using your brand assets without permission. Posts claiming false affiliation. Posts with copyrighted content. Posts impersonating your customer service. Profile Name Only (NOT Actionable) TikTok does NOT take down profiles based solely on: Profile name containing your brand. Bio mentioning your brand (without false claims in posts). Profile picture similarity. Key Difference from Other Platforms : TikTok requires evidence of violation in actual posts/videos, not just profile information. Best Practices ‚úÖ Find specific posts that violate policies. ‚úÖ Provide legitimate profile for comparison. ‚úÖ Explain how the post causes harm. ‚úÖ Include customer reports if available. ‚ùå Don't report profile name alone. ‚ùå Don't submit without LOA. ‚ùå Don't submit without legitimate profile link. Return to Social Media ‚Üí | Return to Home ‚Üí

title: Twitter/X Takedowns
excerpt: Twitter/X Takedowns Choosing the right evidence for X/Twitter cases is crucial. X has a clear and strict definition of impersonation that must be met for successful takedowns. Critical Requirement : X...
content: Twitter/X Takedowns Choosing the right evidence for X/Twitter cases is crucial. X has a clear and strict definition of impersonation that must be met for successful takedowns. Critical Requirement : X/Twitter impersonation must meet at least 2 of the following criteria: Display name. Profile description. Impersonating post. If these criteria are not met, they will reject the takedown. Strict Impersonation Definition What Counts for Impersonation ‚úÖ Counts ‚ùå Does NOT Count Display name (the name shown on profile). Username (@handle). Profile description (bio). Impersonating post (must provide link). Important : The username (@handle) is not considered for impersonation on Twitter/X! Only the display name, bio, and posts matter. Evidence Requirements Mandatory Evidence ‚úÖ Letter of Authorization (LOA) ‚úÖ Meet 2+ Impersonation Criteria Display name uses your brand. Profile description claims affiliation. Posts claim to represent your brand. ‚úÖ Context and Brief Description Type of impersonation. How it harms your brand. Any customer reports. Optional But Recommended Legitimate Profile (helpful but optional for impersonation). Screenshots showing: Profile with display name visible. Bio/description. Impersonating posts. Engagement/confusion. Only for Cases WITHOUT Logo If the fake account does NOT use your logo as profile picture: ‚úÖ Screenshots or Proof of Impersonation Must clearly show 2+ of the criteria. Must be undeniable impersonation. Types of Twitter/X Violations 1. Profile Impersonation Qualifying Example (meets 2+ criteria): ‚úÖ Display name: "CustomerSupport BrandName". ‚úÖ Bio: "Official support for BrandName products". Profile picture: Generic image (not your logo). This meets 2 criteria (display name + bio) = Actionable Non-Qualifying Example (meets only 1): ‚ùå Display name: Regular person's name. ‚úÖ Bio: "I work at BrandName". Profile picture: Personal photo. This meets only 1 criterion = Not Actionable 2. Impersonating Posts If the profile itself doesn't meet impers

title: YouTube Takedowns
excerpt: YouTube Takedowns Evidence required for YouTube cases varies depending on the type of attack you are facing. Evidence by Attack Type 1. Phishing ‚úÖ Evidence Required : Link to the legitimate account be...
content: YouTube Takedowns Evidence required for YouTube cases varies depending on the type of attack you are facing. Evidence by Attack Type 1. Phishing ‚úÖ Evidence Required : Link to the legitimate account being impersonated (if possible). URLs with videos showing the impersonation. If too many videos, provide representative examples. 2. Scams ‚úÖ Evidence Required : Link to the videos performing the scams. Explanation of how the scam scheme works. How it's affecting your brand (if applicable). 3. DMCA (Copyright Infringement) ‚úÖ Evidence Required : Link to the video infringing the DMCA. Timestamp of the infringing part (if specific part of video). Explanation of how the video infringes your copyrights. Letter of Authorization to act on behalf of the brand. 4. Trademark Infringement ‚úÖ Evidence Required : Link to the video or account infringing your trademarks. Timestamp of the infringing part (if specific part of video). Trademark registration for the word being infringed. Letter of Authorization to act on behalf of the brand. Best Practices ‚úÖ Do This Provide specific timestamps for long videos. Include link to legitimate channel for comparison. Explain the harm being caused. Provide trademark/copyright documentation. ‚ùå Don't Do This Don't report entire channels without specific violating videos. Don't submit without proper authorization documents. Don't report Fair Use content (reviews, commentary, parody). Response Times Copyright (DMCA): 24-72 hours typically. Trademark: 5-10 days. Phishing/Scams: 3-7 days. Complex cases: Up to 14 days. Return to Social Media ‚Üí | Return to Home ‚Üí

title: Bulk Reporting
excerpt: Bulk Reporting For certain social media platforms, we offer bulk reporting functionality. Requirements All of the following must be met: ‚úÖ Same Platform All URLs must be from the same platform. ‚úÖ Same...
content: Bulk Reporting For certain social media platforms, we offer bulk reporting functionality. Requirements All of the following must be met: ‚úÖ Same Platform All URLs must be from the same platform. ‚úÖ Same Brand/Person Targeted All incidents target the same brand or person. ‚úÖ Similar/Same Attack Pattern Example: All are fake customer support accounts. Supported Platforms Facebook. Instagram. Scribd. GitBook. Teachable. Telegram. This list is not exhaustive. If unsure whether bulk reporting is supported for a specific platform, contact PhishFort Support. How to Submit Bulk Incidents Submission Format You may include up to 10 URLs : 1 primary URL in the incident form. Up to 9 additional URLs in the incident comments. Process Create incident with type set to "social" . Add primary URL in the main form. Add remaining URLs (up to 9) in comments. Provide evidence for all reported cases. How We Evaluate Success Success Criteria ‚úÖ At least 1 URL successfully taken down = Incident marked successful. ‚ùå No URLs successful = Incident not marked successful. Failed URLs Our Operations team will notify you of failed URLs. Resubmit failed URLs in new incident for another attempt. Cannot re-report in bulk - must be individual incidents. Important Limitations ‚ö†Ô∏è Domain Bulk Reporting NOT Available Important : Bulk reporting of domains is not available at this time. Do NOT include domain-level takedown requests in bulk social submissions. Each domain must be submitted as a separate incident. Best Practices ‚úÖ Do This Verify all URLs are from same platform. Ensure same attack pattern. Provide evidence for each URL. Submit as "social" incident type. Include context in comments. ‚ùå Don't Do This Don't mix platforms in one submission. Don't exceed 10 URLs. Don't include domains in social bulk reports. Don't resubmit failed URLs in bulk again. Don't submit without evidence. Example Bulk Submission Scenario : 7 fake Facebook customer support accounts Submission : Platform : Facebook. Pattern : All

title: Fake News
excerpt: Fake News In cases involving suspected fake news, it is important to note that such material is often hosted on legitimate news platforms and distributed across multiple credible sources. Important : ...
content: Fake News In cases involving suspected fake news, it is important to note that such material is often hosted on legitimate news platforms and distributed across multiple credible sources. Important : Requests to remove news content are generally declined by hosting providers and authorities unless supported by compelling legal documentation. When Takedowns Are Possible Takedown efforts for news articles and editorial content are typically only successful when one of the following conditions is met: 1. Verifiable Evidence ‚úÖ Clear demonstration that the content is false or misleading. 2. Court Order ‚úÖ Court order issued by a competent legal authority mandating removal. Evidence Requirements ‚úÖ Fact-Based Rebuttal Correction from credible source. Demonstrates claims are false or misleading. ‚úÖ Official Statements Press releases from client or relevant authorities. Disproves reported information. ‚úÖ Screenshots/Archives Including timestamps. Preserve the version in question. ‚úÖ Evidence of Harm Reputational damage. Financial loss. Legal consequences. ‚úÖ Statements from Affected Individuals Company representatives refuting content. ‚úÖ Court Order or Legal Opinion (if available) States content constitutes defamation or misinformation. Why Takedowns Are Difficult Press Freedom Protections Hosting providers respect editorial independence. Platforms protect journalistic content. Legal frameworks favor free speech. Legitimate Platform Hosting News sites are credible, established platforms. Not the same as phishing or malicious sites. Require stronger legal justification. Recommended Approach Legal Consultation : We advise clients to consult with their legal teams to assess the possibility of pursuing a court order. This approach offers the most reliable path to achieving content removal in fake news cases. Alternative Actions While pursuing takedown: Issue official rebuttals. Contact platform directly. Seek corrections or retractions. Publish counter-evidence. Pursue defamation cla

title: Scams
excerpt: Scams A scam incident occurs when a website or its content appears legitimate, but the advertised service is not delivered. Simple Example : If you pay for a coffee but receive only water or nothing a...
content: Scams A scam incident occurs when a website or its content appears legitimate, but the advertised service is not delivered. Simple Example : If you pay for a coffee but receive only water or nothing at all, that is a scam. Challenge with Scam Cases In general, scams do not target our customers directly, but they can still be affected by them. Difficulty : Obtaining proof can be challenging, which limits our possible courses of action and might affect our ability to take them down. Evidence Requirements ‚úÖ Context Describing the Scam How the scam works. What is promised vs. what is delivered. ‚úÖ Evidence of Purchased Services/Goods Specifically, the text used to scam contains a clear payment request. Screenshots of the offer. Transaction records. ‚úÖ Proof Agreement Was Not Completed No service delivered. Counterfeit goods delivered. Service different from what was promised. Communication proving non-delivery. Types of Scam Evidence Court-Level Evidence (Strongest) For strongest cases, provide: Service Promised : Clear documentation of what was offered. Proof of Transaction : Payment receipts, bank statements, transaction IDs. Proof of Non-Delivery : Shipping records showing nothing sent, or proof item was counterfeit. Customer Reports Multiple victims with same experience. Pattern of non-delivery. Complaints filed with authorities. Platform Violations Terms of service violations. False advertising. Fraudulent claims. Why Proof Is Critical Without clear evidence that: Money was exchanged. Service/goods were promised. Promise was not fulfilled. ...the case appears as a "he said, she said" dispute rather than provable fraud. Best Practices ‚úÖ Do This Document everything before purchasing. Screenshot the offer/promises. Keep all communication records. Save payment receipts. Document non-delivery. ‚ùå Don't Do This Don't report suspicions without evidence. Don't expect takedown without transaction proof. Don't submit without clear scam pattern. Alternative Actions If evidence i
